questions.text: A 34-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department following a high-speed motor vehicle collision in which she was the restrained driver. On arrival, she has a cervical collar in place and is unresponsive. Her temperature is 36.7°C (98.0°F), pulse is 70/min, and blood pressure is 131/76 mm Hg. Her pupils are dilated and not reactive to light. She is unresponsive to noxious stimuli. She is intubated, and mechanical ventilation is begun. Serum concentrations of electrolytes, urea nitrogen, and creatinine are within the reference range. Toxicology screening is negative. A CT scan of the head without contrast shows a massive intracranial bleed and a cervical spine injury at the level of C3. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in diagnosing brain death?

choices.text: Oculocephalic reflex test
Electroencephalography
Magnetic resonance angiography
Deep tendon reflex testing
Transcranial Doppler ultrasonography
Corneal reflex test

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

The oculocephalic reflex is a component of the neurological exam that is usually performed prior to declaring brain death. However, oculocephalic reflex testing requires quickly turning the patient's head to one side and it should not be performed in patients with C-spine injuries. This patient was recently in an automobile accident and has a confirmed cervical spine injury at C3, which is a contraindication to this test.
Image Description:

Normal: The eyes remain fixed on an object despite rapid, passive movement of the patient's head.

Pathological: The eyes remain midorbit during rapid, passive movement of the patient's head; this indicates a defective brainstem reflex.

B) INCORRECT:

Electroencephalography is an ancillary test that shows absent brain electrical activity (i.e., flat EEG) in brain death and that may be used to confirm the diagnosis of brain death if the clinical neurological examination is inconclusive or cannot be completed reliably. Prior to performing this test, however, it is necessary to complete a full clinical evaluation of brain death, which has not yet occurred.

C) INCORRECT:

Magnetic resonance angiography is an ancillary test in the assessment of brain death used to evaluate for the presence or absence of cerebral blood flow (with the latter being a sign of brain death) if the clinical examination is inconclusive. Prior to performing any ancillary tests, however, this patient requires a full clinical evaluation of brain death, which has not yet occurred.

D) INCORRECT:

Deep tendon reflexes are occasionally seen in brain-dead patients who have intact spinal cords, as these reflexes do not require brain activity. Though they should be tested as part of the complete neurological examination, the presence of deep tendon reflexes should not be misinterpreted as evidence of brainstem function and cannot be used to diagnose brain death.

E) INCORRECT:

Transcranial Doppler ultrasonography is an ancillary test in the assessment of brain death used to evaluate the cerebral circulation if the clinical examination is inconclusive or cannot be completed reliably. Prior to performing any ancillary tests, however, this patient requires a full clinical evaluation of brain death, which has not yet occurred.

F) CORRECT:

Corneal reflex testing is indicated in this patient as part of a full neurologic workup for brain death. The accepted criteria for this diagnosis are presence of coma (of known cause), absence of a brain-originating motor response (including response to noxious stimuli), cranial nerve areflexia, and apnea. Currently, this patient has only met two of these requirements (coma, absent response to noxious stimuli). The corneal reflex is one of the brainstem reflexes that must be tested (along with the gag reflex, cough reflex, and pupillary light reflex) prior to declaring brain death. If all these reflexes are negative, an apnea test is performed to confirm the diagnosis.
Image Description:

Simplified representation of the pupillary light reflex (II → IIIa), corneal reflex (V → VII), and vestibuloocular reflex (VIII → III)

(II = pretectal area (afferent part of the optic nerve); IIIa = Edinger–Westphal nucleus: III = oculomotor nucleus; V = trigeminal nerve nucleus; VII = facial motor nucleus; VIII = vestibular nucleus)
questions.hint: This patient meets the clinical criteria for brain death (here coma due to a massive intracranial bleed). Neurological examination shows an absent pupillary light reflex, indicating injury to the midbrain. The next step in diagnosis is assessment of damage to the pons.

questions.text: A 75-year-old woman with metastatic colon cancer comes to the physician requesting assistance in ending her life. She states: “I just can't take it anymore; the pain is unbearable. Please help me die.” Current medications include 10 mg oral hydrocodone every 12 hours. Her cancer has progressed despite chemotherapy and she is very frail. She lives alone and has no close family. Which of the following is the most appropriate initial action by the physician?

choices.text: Submit a referral to psychiatry
Submit a referral to hospice care
Consult with the local ethics committee
Increase her pain medication dose
Initiate authorization of physician-assisted dying

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Depression and/or anxiety are common in terminally ill patients and should be evaluated for every patient. However, this patient's primary concern is somatic pain. If the physician had good reason to believe that depression and/or anxiety were primary components of this patient's pain, a referral to psychiatry would be a good option.

B) INCORRECT:

A referral to hospice care can be submitted if this patient is deemed to have less than 6 months to live. However, this patient has asked her physician for assistance with ending her life, and this concern should be addressed by other actions prior to referring to hospice.

C) INCORRECT:

Consulting an ethics committee can be helpful in cases where a patient lacks capacity to make decisions pertaining to his or her medical care or when there are disputes between surrogate decision makers (or medical power of attorney). Since this patient does not lack decision-making capacity, other steps should be taken to address her request.

D) CORRECT:

The most appropriate action from the physician at this time is to optimize the patient's pain control regimen. This patient is requesting physician-assisted dying, which is illegal in the majority of states and highly regulated in the jurisdictions that allow it. Her pain is not well controlled and adequate analgesia may change her wish to die.

E) INCORRECT:

Physician-assisted dying is illegal in the majority of states in the US and highly regulated in those where it is legal. Although this patient is requesting assistance to end her life, her wish may change as the physician addresses her primary concern.

questions.text: A 26-year-old man is brought to the emergency department 30 minutes after he was involved in a high-speed motorcycle collision. On arrival, he is unresponsive to painful stimuli. Physical examination shows fixed and bilaterally dilated pupils and an open head wound with visible brain matter in the left occipital region. After transfer to the neurocritical care unit, two full neurological examinations and an apnea test are performed and it is determined that no brain stem reflexes are present. The patient is declared brain dead. The attending neurosurgeon speaks to the family and explains the meaning of brain death and that the patient will not recover. His family members say they are hopeful because the patient still moves his fingers when they speak to him or touch his hand. Despite a thorough explanation by the physician that those movements do not mean that the brain is functioning, the family insists on continuing life-supporting measures because they believe he will wake up. There is enough space in the hospital for the patient to continue to remain on life support while the health care team and the family are trying to reach an agreement. Which of the following is the most appropriate action by the physician?

choices.text: Bring the case to the hospital ethics committee
Discontinue all life-supporting measures and exclude the family from the decision-making process
Explain that the patient is dead and life support has to be stopped because the treatment of other patients is more important now
Respect the family’s autonomy and maintain life support indefinitely
Obtain a CT angiography to confirm absent intracranial blood flow

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

When there is a difference of opinion between the family and the medical team over life-sustaining measures in a patient with established brain death, the American Medical Association Principles of Medical Ethics recommend seeking consultation from an independent, objective medium, like an ethics committee. However, note that it is medically appropriate to discontinue therapy after brain death. Technically, the physician does not need to obtain the family's permission to remove life support. Nevertheless, recommendations mostly advocate an empathetic approach, which meets the family's emotional needs and tries to reach a mutual understanding.

B) INCORRECT:

Discontinuing therapy after brain death is medically appropriate, and the physician does not need to obtain the family's permission to end life-sustaining measures. However, excluding the family without further efforts at communication would be unempathetic and not responsive to the family's emotional needs. The American Medical Association Principles of Medical Ethics recommend an alternative approach in the case of a difference of opinion over life support in a patient with brain death.

C) INCORRECT:

Discontinuing therapy after brain death is appropriate, and the reasons for doing so should be communicated transparently and empathetically to the patient's surrogate (in this case, his family). However, this should be done with care and respect for the family's emotional needs. Although the capacities of the health care system are limited and other patients need treatment, it is insensitive and potentially confrontational to tell the family about that at this point. The American Medical Association Principles of Medical Ethics recommend an alternative approach in the case of a difference of opinion over life support in a patient with brain death.

D) INCORRECT:

The patient, or if applicable his surrogate decision-maker (in this case, the family), should be included in the decision-making process whenever possible, and their autonomy needs to be respected. However, it is medically appropriate to discontinue therapy after brain death.

E) INCORRECT:

CT angiography of the brain is an accepted ancillary method for establishing brain death. However, it is not necessary for this patient whose diagnosis has already been properly established by two different neurological examinations showing the absence of brainstem reflexes, and an apnea test. Ancillary brain death tests are only indicated when the neurological examination or the apnea test cannot be performed (e.g., severe facial trauma).
questions.hint: Brain death is defined as irreversible, complete loss of function of the whole brain. This diagnosis will guide further management, a delicate task that needs careful handling.

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman is evaluated by the physician 3 days after a high-speed motorcycle collision in which she was the unrestrained driver. A neurologic examination performed by a resident at the time of admission showed nonreactive pupils and absent brainstem and deep tendon reflexes; a CT scan of the head showed a massive epidural hematoma. The patient is currently intubated and mechanically ventilated, and not receiving any paralytic or sedative medications. Her temperature is 36.5°C (97.7°F), pulse is 70/min, and blood pressure is 125/75 mm Hg. Physical examination shows dilated, nonreactive pupils and absent corneal, gag, and cough reflexes. There is no eye movement upon irrigation of the external auditory canal with cold water. She does not respond to painful stimuli applied to the shins, sternum, and temporomandibular joint. Deep tendon reflexes are 1+ in the right ankle and 2+ in the left biceps. Serum concentrations of electrolytes, urea, creatinine, and glucose are within the reference range. Urinary toxicology screening is negative. The apnea test is positive. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in diagnosis?

choices.text: Somatosensory evoked potentials test
No further workup is indicated
Nerve conduction test
Transcranial Doppler ultrasonography
Electroencephalography

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Measurement of somatosensory evoked potential (SSEP) is an ancillary test to diagnose brain death; absence of SSEPs from both the parietal cortices supports a diagnosis of brain death. This patient does not require SSEP measurement.

B) CORRECT:

To determine brain death, a physician must first identify evidence of a known cause for irreversible brain damage (e.g., a massive epidural hematoma on imaging) and exclude confounders (e.g., sedative/paralytic use, drug intoxication, severe metabolic derangements, hypotension, hypothermia). The physician must then demonstrate via examination that the patient is comatose, does not have brain-mediated motor responses (e.g., decorticate or decerebrate posturing, facial grimacing) to noxious stimuli applied above and below the neck, has brainstem areflexia, and has a positive apnea test. Finally, the evaluation must be independently repeated by another physician and the findings on reevaluation must be in concordance with the first physician's findings. For children and patients who received cardiopulmonary resuscitation, an observation period is required before the reevaluation. If all of these criteria are met, brain death can be declared without performing any ancillary testing.

Ancillary testing using a brain blood flow study (e.g., cerebral angiography, cerebral scintigraphy, transcranial Doppler) or an electrophysiological study (e.g., electroencephalography, evoked potentials) is indicated if any of the aforementioned criteria are not met, if any of the steps of the examination cannot be performed or yield inconclusive results, and for children below 1 year of age. If organ procurement from the patient is being considered, none of the physicians involved in determining brain death can be involved in the organ transplantation process or care of the organ recipient.

C) INCORRECT:

A nerve conduction test is used in the workup of certain brain death mimics, such as severe Guillain-Barre syndrome, but is not used to diagnose brain death from trauma, as seen here.

D) INCORRECT:

Transcranial Doppler ultrasonography is an ancillary test to diagnose brain death; evidence of high resistance in intracranial blood vessels (e.g., decreased systolic flow velocity with no diastolic blood flow) suggests brain death. This patient does not require transcranial doppler ultrasonography.

E) INCORRECT:

Electroencephalography (EEG) is an ancillary test to diagnose brain death; electrocerebral silence on EEG indicates brain death. This patient does not require electroencephalography.
questions.hint: The absence of the pupillary reflex, vestibuloocular reflex, corneal reflex, gag reflex, and cough reflex indicate brainstem areflexia, which is one of the criteria for brain death. The presence of cardiac activity and spontaneous or reflex motor responses as a result of bioelectrical activity restricted to the spinal cord, peripheral nerves, and muscles (e.g., deep tendon reflexes, Babinski sign, fasciculations, myoclonus) should not be interpreted as evidence against brain death.

questions.text: A 66-year-old man is brought to the emergency department by ambulance 30 minutes after having fallen from the balcony of his fifth-floor apartment. Emergency medical technicians arrived at the scene of injury 10 minutes after the fall and performed cardiopulmonary resuscitation (CPR) en route to the hospital. On arrival, he is unconscious and has a Glasgow coma score of 3. His temperature is 36.4°C (97.5°F) and he has nonpalpable pulses with asystole on ECG. CPR is continued and the patient is intubated and mechanically ventilated. Chest auscultation discloses clear lung fields with bilateral air entry and absent heart sounds. Point of care ultrasound shows visible sliding of the pleura and no cardiac wall motion. There is no evidence of fluid in the pericardium, ventricular dilation, or inferior vena cava collapse. Arterial blood gas analysis on 100% oxygen shows a pH of 7.36 and an oxygen saturation of 99%. Despite continuing CPR for another 20 minutes, the ECG recordings persistently show asystole. The pupils are 9 mm and nonreactive to light. End-tidal carbon dioxide is 8 mm Hg (N = 35–45) and serum electrolyte concentrations are within normal limits. Two emergency medicine residents in their first postgraduate year ask the attending physician if they can practice femoral vein catheterization and scalpel cricothyroidotomy on the patient. There are no advance directives or emergency medical contacts in the patient's electronic health record. At this time, which of the following is the most appropriate instruction by the attending physician to the team treating the patient?

choices.text: Continue CPR and attempt to contact the patient's family
Pronounce death and attempt to contact the patient's family
Pronounce death and allow both procedures to be performed under supervision
Pronounce death and allow femoral vein catheterization under supervision
Continue CPR and allow femoral vein catheterization under supervision
Continue CPR and allow both procedures to be performed under supervision

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

When the deceased's preferences are not known (e.g., no advance directives), consent from the next of kin should be obtained before any training procedure can be performed, so it is appropriate to contact this patient's family. However, considering all the scenario-specific features associated with a poor outcome, continuing CPR would be futile.

B) CORRECT:

Although no single factor or specific combination of factors can clearly predict the outcome of resuscitative efforts in a hospital setting, it is appropriate to pronounce death in this patient when all the scenario-specific features are taken into account (e.g., effective CPR for > 30 minutes without ROSC, no shockable rhythm). Performing procedures on newly deceased patients can provide valuable hands-on training for inexperienced health care providers. However, consent from the next of kin is required for each procedure if the deceased's preferences are not known. According to the Uniform Anatomical Gifts Act, in the absence of an advance directive or emergency medical contacts in the patient's records, emergency physicians and medical technicians are allowed to search through the patient's belongings and may share their personal information (e.g., social security number) with authorities to identify them.

If the next of kin cannot be located within a reasonable time frame, it is ethically inappropriate to use the body of a deceased patient for training purposes, regardless of the degree of invasiveness of the procedure. If consent is obtained, the training procedures should be organized systematically and conducted under close supervision while ensuring a respectful environment for the deceased and their family.

C) INCORRECT:

Considering all the scenario-specific features associated with a poor outcome, it is appropriate to pronounce this patient dead. However, when the deceased's preferences are not known (e.g., no advance directives), consent from the next of kin should be obtained before any training procedure is performed, regardless of the level of supervision.

D) INCORRECT:

Considering all the scenario-specific features associated with a poor outcome, it is appropriate to pronounce this patient dead. However, when the deceased's preferences are not known (e.g., no advance directives), consent from the next of kin should be obtained before any training procedure is performed, regardless of the degree of invasiveness or level of supervision.

E) INCORRECT:

Considering all the scenario-specific features associated with a poor outcome, continuing CPR would be futile. When the deceased's preferences are not known (e.g., no advance directives), consent from the next of kin should be obtained before any training procedure can be performed, regardless of the degree of invasiveness or level of supervision.

F) INCORRECT:

Considering all the scenario-specific features associated with a poor outcome, continuing CPR would be futile. When the deceased's preferences are not known (e.g., no advance directives), consent from the next of kin should be obtained before any training procedure can be performed, regardless of the level of supervision.
questions.hint: In this patient, reversible causes of posttraumatic cardiac arrest (e.g., tension pneumothorax, massive hemothorax, cardiac tamponade, exsanguination, asphyxiation) have been excluded. Before making a decision, the attending physician must consider the following scenario-specific features: high-energy trauma, out-of-hospital cardiac arrest, late initiation of CPR, a cumulative CPR time > 30 minutes without return of spontaneous circulation (ROSC) or a rhythm change at any point, end-tidal CO2  < 10 mm Hg, and an examination finding suggestive of brainstem areflexia.

questions.text: A 44-year-old man is brought to the emergency department after being involved in a motor vehicle collision in which he was the unrestrained driver. On arrival, he is unresponsive. A CT scan of the head without contrast shows a massive intracranial hemorrhage. The patient is admitted to the intensive care unit. He is currently intubated and mechanically ventilated and not receiving any paralytic or sedative medications. Temperature is 34.9°C (94.8°F), pulse is 88/min, and blood pressure is 105/62 mm Hg after intravenous administration of norepinephrine. Neurological examination on admission shows dilated, nonreactive pupils and absent corneal, gag, and cough reflexes. There is no eye movement upon irrigation of the external auditory canal with cold water. A subsequent independent evaluation by another physician is concordant with these findings. Serum concentrations of electrolytes, glucose, urea nitrogen, and creatinine are within the reference ranges. Which of the following is the most appropriate action at this time?

choices.text: Perform an apnea test
Discontinue norepinephrine and repeat tests
No further action is indicated
Perform a somatosensory evoked potentials test
Correct hypothermia

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Apnea testing is an essential part of diagnosing brain death and is typically carried out after all other criteria (e.g., coma, brainstem areflexia) have been met. However, because certain confounding factors can lead to misdiagnosis of brain death, there are prerequisites for apnea testing.

B) INCORRECT:

Adequate cerebral perfusion, i.e. systolic blood pressure (SBP) > 100 mm Hg is required for the diagnosis of brain death. If SBP falls below 100 mm Hg, vasopressors (e.g., norepinephrine) should be administered. Discontinuing norepinephrine in this patient may lower SBP and impede clinical judgment.

C) INCORRECT:

In order to diagnose brain death, there must be evidence of a specific cause (e.g., massive intracranial hemorrhage), and neurological examination must confirm coma and brainstem areflexia. Although this patient meets these criteria, diagnosis of brain death also requires the absence of confounding factors, and the neurological examination should include apnea testing.

D) INCORRECT:

Somatosensory evoked potentials (SSEP) are ancillary tests for brain death that are only indicated if clinical examination and/or apnea testing are inconclusive or if the patient is younger than one year of age. Ancillary testing is not indicated at this point.

E) CORRECT:

Confounding factors may interfere with brain death assessment and should be corrected before diagnosis. Core body temperature must be > 36.0°C (96.8°F) for a minimum of 24 hours because hypothermia may impede neurological assessment and delay the increase in pCO2 in apnea testing. Normothermia can be achieved by covering the patient with warming blankets and/or administering warm intravenous fluids. Other causes of impaired brain function, such as poisoning, drug intoxication, electrolyte imbalances, and hypotension as well as conditions that can mimic brain death (e.g., locked-in syndrome) should be ruled out and corrected if possible. Systolic blood pressure must be > 100 mm Hg, which may require the administration of vasopressors (e.g., norepinephrine). If these prerequisites are met and patients still present with coma and brainstem areflexia, apnea testing can be performed for a definitive diagnosis of brain death.
questions.hint: Coma and signs of brainstem areflexia (e.g., dilated, nonreactive pupils and absence of corneal, gag, and cough reflexes) along with radiological evidence of acute, severe damage to the CNS (e.g., massive intracranial hemorrhage) suggest brain death.

questions.text:
A 4-month-old boy is being evaluated in the pediatric intensive care unit. He was found unresponsive and pulseless after nap time at his day-care center and underwent prolonged resuscitation.
He was admitted to the pediatric intensive care unit on mechanical ventilation, and his cardiovascular and respiratory systems were stabilized over a period of 2 days. His blood pressure is now normal for age, and his oxygen saturation and arterial blood gas results are within normal ranges on minimal ventilator settings. He is normothermic, his electrolyte levels are within normal ranges, and he has been off both sedation and muscle relaxants for more than 48 hours, with no apparent movement or activity.
A neurologic examination assessing for brain death reveals no spontaneous movement, no response to pain, and no brain-stem reflexes, including oculocephalic and oculovestibular reflexes.
Which one of the following tests should be performed as a next step in the evaluation for brain death in this patient?

choices.text: Electroencephalogram
Apnea testing
Radionuclide cerebral blood-flow study
Transcranial Doppler imaging
CT angiography of the brain

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Electroencephalography should not be used as an ancillary study in the evaluation for brain death in children.

B) CORRECT:

This patient experienced cardiopulmonary arrest with hypoxic injury that is not expected to be reversible. He exhibits no preservation of brain activity. He is normothermic without electrolyte or metabolic disturbances, and there is no presumed medication effect. At least 48 hours have passed since the acute brain injury occurred. Testing for brain death is therefore appropriate.

Determination of brain death in infants and children requires evidence of permanent loss of function of the entire brain, including the brain stem, resulting in coma, brain-stem areflexia, and apnea in the setting of adequate stimulus.

Before a determination of brain death is initiated, there should be a period of observation to ensure permanency. For infants and children younger than 24 months, clinicians should wait at least 48 hours after the acute brain injury before initiating brain death evaluation. For those older than 2 years with hypoxic-ischemic brain injury, an observation period of at least 24 hours is recommended.

Pediatric brain death evaluation requires two neurologic examinations performed at least 12 hours apart, with each examination conducted by a different appropriately trained clinician involved in the care of the child. Neurologic testing should assess for spontaneous movement, response to pain, and brain-stem reflexes (including pupillary, oculocephalic, oculovestibular, corneal, gag, and cough reflexes).

Apnea testing is also required with each neurologic examination to certify brain death. For this test, the patient must start with normal arterial blood gas findings. The patient is preoxygenated and then disconnected from the ventilator; blood gas levels and hemodynamic stability are monitored, and the patient is observed for spontaneous breaths. The test is considered consistent with brain death if there is no spontaneous respiratory effort from the time the test starts until (a) the partial pressure of carbon dioxide reaches ≥60 mm Hg and is at least 20 mm Hg above baseline and (b) the arterial pH is less than 7.30.

Clinicians performing evaluations for brain death should be familiar with the brain death protocols at their institution.

Key learning point: If a complete neurologic examination shows no brain activity in a child, the next step in the evaluation for brain death is apnea testing.

C) INCORRECT:

Ancillary testing is not required for determination of brain death and should not be considered a substitute for the neurologic examinations. Such testing may be needed, however, if components of the examinations or apnea testing cannot be completed safely (because of the patient’s clinical condition), if there is uncertainty about the results of the neurologic examinations, or if a medication or metabolic effect may be present. Currently, the only accepted ancillary tests in children are radionuclide cerebral blood-flow studies and four-vessel catheter angiography. In this particular case, the standard neurologic and apnea testing is not contraindicated, so ancillary testing is not required at this time.

D) INCORRECT:

Transcranial Doppler imaging should not be used as an ancillary study in the evaluation for brain death in children.

E) INCORRECT:

CT angiography of the brain should not be used as an ancillary study in the evaluation for brain death in children.

questions.text: An 84-year-old man with advanced pancreatic cancer is admitted for severe, intractable abdominal pain. Despite escalating intravenous opioid doses, he remains in constant distress, grimacing and moaning. His respiratory rate is 12/min, and his blood pressure is 100/60 mm Hg. He has declined further surgeries or aggressive interventions, focusing on comfort measures only. The palliative care team is considering increasing the opioid infusion but worries about potential respiratory depression and hastening death. Which approach best applies the relevant ethical principle to manage his pain at this stage?

choices.text: Stop opioid therapy altogether to remove any possibility of hastening death
Escalate opioid dosing primarily to relieve pain, accepting any respiratory compromise as an unintended effect
Continue the current regimen to avoid any risk of sedation, despite ongoing severe pain
Switch to only non-opioid treatments to completely prevent respiratory depression

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Ceasing opioid therapy due to fear of respiratory depression disregards the ethical commitment to alleviate suffering in advanced disease. The patient's stable respiratory rate suggests tolerance to the regimen. Palliative care supports interventions for pain relief, even with potential secondary effects, prioritizing patient comfort and respecting their wishes.

B) CORRECT:

The principle of double effect justifies escalating opioid doses to relieve severe pain, even if it risks respiratory depression as an unintended effect. This ethical doctrine allows actions with both beneficial and harmful outcomes if the intent is to alleviate suffering and the harm is not disproportionate to the benefit. In palliative care, especially at the end of life, controlled opioid escalation prioritizes symptom relief, with adverse effects managed proactively.

Key learning point: The principle of double effect allows for actions that have both a positive and a negative effect, as long as the negative effect is not intended and the positive effect is the primary goal.

C) INCORRECT:

Maintaining inadequate opioid dosing to prevent sedation neglects the primary goal of palliative care: relieving suffering. The doctrine of double effect supports opioid escalation to alleviate pain, with sedation as a secondary effect. The patient's advanced disease and preference for comfort measures justify increasing analgesia despite potential sedation.

D) INCORRECT:

Non-opioid treatments alone are insufficient for severe pain in advanced pancreatic cancer. Palliative care involves careful opioid titration to relieve suffering while monitoring for adverse effects. Opioid use, especially in tolerant patients, minimizes respiratory depression risk, balancing symptom control with side effects.

questions.text: A 32-year-old man is brought to the emergency department after being found unresponsive at home. Cardiopulmonary resuscitation is initiated by paramedics, but he remains unresponsive on arrival. His family says he appeared healthy on the previous day. He has no significant past medical history and takes no medications. He has no history of substance use and is not married. Physical examination shows a comatose man who is intubated and mechanically ventilated. His temperature is 36.8°C (98.2°F), pulse is 82/min, blood pressure is 122/76 mm Hg, and respirations are controlled by the ventilator. He has fixed, dilated pupils, absent corneal and gag reflexes, and no spontaneous movements. Apnea testing confirms the absence of spontaneous respirations. The attending physician discloses the diagnosis of brain death to the family and gives some time to process the information. In a follow-up conversation, the physician addresses the topic of organ donation. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step?

choices.text: Request approval from the hospital ethics committee before proceeding
Wait for a mandatory 24-hour period after brain death is declared before proceeding
Notify the local organ procurement organization for evaluation
Proceed only if the patient had a documented donor card
Obtain written consent for organ donation from the patient's mother

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Although the ethics committee may be involved in complex or disputed cases, its approval is not necessary for standard organ procurement procedures once brain death has been declared.

B) INCORRECT:

There is no mandatory waiting period between brain death and the initiation of the organ procurement process. Once brain death is confirmed, the patient is legally dead, and organ procurement procedures may proceed following established protocols. Prolonging the interval without a specific clinical or legal reason may reduce organ viability and is not a standard procedural step in organ donation protocols.

C) CORRECT:

Federal regulations and hospital policy require that all potential organ donors be reported to a local organ procurement organization (OPO) as soon as brain death is established or imminent, unless the deceased patient has specifically declined to become a donor (e.g., in an advance directive). The OPO is responsible for evaluating medical suitability and discussing organ donation with the family. Physicians and hospital staff should not initiate the process for donation themselves (e.g., by obtaining consent), as this may result in conflicts of interest and reduce consent rates. OPO staff are specially trained to provide support, address questions, and facilitate the process ethically and sensitively. Early notification preserves organ viability and ensures that the process respects medical, ethical, and legal standards.

D) INCORRECT:

Documented donor status is helpful but not required to initiate the process of organ donation. While a documented donor card or registration in a donor registry is legally binding in many states, organ donation evaluation should proceed even if such documentation is not available. In many cases, family members or legally authorized representatives may make decisions about donation in the absence of documented donor status, provided that other requirements and protocols are followed.

E) INCORRECT:

Written consent for organ donation may sometimes be required from the next of kin, depending on state law and the patient’s documented wishes. However, the process for obtaining and validating consent is standardized and typically involves designated professionals who are trained in these sensitive discussions.
questions.hint: There are standardized processes for donor candidates who did not explicitly decline to donate organs.

questions.text: A 66-year-old man is brought to the emergency department by ambulance 30 minutes after having fallen from the balcony of his fifth-floor apartment. Emergency medical technicians arrived at the scene of injury 10 minutes after the fall and performed cardiopulmonary resuscitation (CPR) en route to the hospital. On arrival, he is unconscious and has a Glasgow coma score of 3. His temperature is 36.4°C (97.5°F) and he has nonpalpable pulses with asystole on ECG. CPR is continued and the patient is intubated and mechanically ventilated. Chest auscultation discloses clear lung fields with bilateral air entry and absent heart sounds. Point of care ultrasound shows visible sliding of the pleura and no cardiac wall motion. There is no evidence of fluid in the pericardium, ventricular dilation, or inferior vena cava collapse. Arterial blood gas analysis on 100% oxygen shows a pH of 7.36 and an oxygen saturation of 99%. Despite continuing CPR for another 20 minutes, the ECG recordings persistently show asystole. The pupils are 9 mm and nonreactive to light. End-tidal carbon dioxide is 8 mm Hg (N = 35–45) and serum electrolyte concentrations are within normal limits. Two emergency medicine residents in their first postgraduate year ask the attending physician if they can practice femoral vein catheterization and scalpel cricothyroidotomy on the patient. There are no advance directives or emergency medical contacts in the patient's electronic health record. At this time, which of the following is the most appropriate instruction by the attending physician to the team treating the patient?

choices.text: Continue CPR and attempt to contact the patient's family
Pronounce death and attempt to contact the patient's family
Pronounce death and allow both procedures to be performed under supervision
Continue CPR and allow femoral vein catheterization under supervision
Continue CPR and allow both procedures to be performed under supervision

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

When the deceased's preferences are not known (e.g., no advance directives), consent from the next of kin should be obtained before any training procedure can be performed, so it is appropriate to contact this patient's family. However, considering all the scenario-specific features associated with a poor outcome, continuing CPR would be futile.

B) CORRECT:

Although no single factor or specific combination of factors can clearly predict the outcome of resuscitative efforts in a hospital setting, it is appropriate to pronounce death in this patient when all the scenario-specific features are taken into account (e.g., effective CPR for > 30 minutes without ROSC, no shockable rhythm). Performing procedures on newly deceased patients can provide valuable hands-on training for inexperienced health care providers. However, consent from the next of kin is required for each procedure if the deceased's preferences are not known. According to the Uniform Anatomical Gifts Act, in the absence of an advance directive or emergency medical contacts in the patient's records, emergency physicians and medical technicians are allowed to search through the patient's belongings and may share their personal information (e.g., social security number) with authorities to identify them.

If the next of kin cannot be located within a reasonable time frame, it is ethically inappropriate to use the body of a deceased patient for training purposes, regardless of the degree of invasiveness of the procedure. If consent is obtained, the training procedures should be organized systematically and conducted under close supervision while ensuring a respectful environment for the deceased and their family.

C) INCORRECT:

Considering all the scenario-specific features associated with a poor outcome, it is appropriate to pronounce this patient dead. However, when the deceased's preferences are not known (e.g., no advance directives), consent from the next of kin should be obtained before any training procedure is performed, regardless of the level of supervision.

D) INCORRECT:

Considering all the scenario-specific features associated with a poor outcome, continuing CPR would be futile. When the deceased's preferences are not known (e.g., no advance directives), consent from the next of kin should be obtained before any training procedure can be performed, regardless of the degree of invasiveness or level of supervision.

E) INCORRECT:
